canonical_explanation.text: A magnet is an object that attracts materials made of iron, nickel, and cobalt. Magnets were first discovered as natural rocks called magnetite or lodestone. Every magnet has two poles — a North pole and a South pole. Like poles repel each other and unlike poles attract each other. A freely suspended magnet always points in the north-south direction, which is the principle behind a magnetic compass. Magnets can be made artificially by rubbing a piece of iron with a magnet or by using electricity.
rules: Magnetite (lodestone) is a naturally occurring magnet.
Artificial magnets come in different shapes: bar, horseshoe, cylindrical, ring.
Every magnet has two poles: North (N) and South (S).
Like poles repel; unlike poles attract.
A freely suspended magnet always aligns in the north-south direction.
Magnetic materials: iron, nickel, cobalt, steel are attracted by magnets.
Non-magnetic materials: wood, plastic, rubber, glass are not attracted by magnets.
A magnetic compass contains a magnetic needle that points north-south.
Magnets can be made by the stroking (rubbing) method or using electricity.
Magnets lose their magnetism by heating, hammering, or dropping repeatedly.

questions.question_text: The natural magnet is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Magnetite (also called lodestone) is a naturally occurring magnetic rock. It was the first type of magnet discovered by humans. Bar magnets, horseshoe magnets, and electromagnets are all artificial magnets.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bar magnets and horseshoe magnets are artificial magnets made by humans. Electromagnets are made using electricity. Magnetite (lodestone) is the only natural magnet among the options.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an artificial magnet?
questions.explanation_correct: A bar magnet is made by humans through processes like rubbing or using electricity. It is an artificial magnet. Lodestone and magnetite are natural magnets, and iron ore is a natural mineral.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lodestone and magnetite are natural magnets found in nature. Iron ore is a natural mineral. A bar magnet is manufactured by humans, making it an artificial magnet.

questions.question_text: Magnets were first discovered by shepherds in a region called Magnesia in ancient Greece.
questions.explanation_correct: According to the historical account, shepherds in Magnesia (ancient Greece) noticed that their iron-tipped shoes and iron staffs stuck to certain rocks. These rocks were natural magnets (magnetite). The word 'magnet' is derived from 'Magnesia.'
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is true. The word 'magnet' comes from Magnesia, a region in ancient Greece, where natural magnetic rocks were first discovered.

questions.question_text: How many poles does a magnet have?
questions.explanation_correct: Every magnet has exactly two poles: a North pole (N) and a South pole (S). The magnetic strength is strongest at the poles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A magnet always has exactly two poles — North and South. It cannot have one, three, or four poles. Even if you break a magnet, each piece will have its own two poles.

questions.question_text: What happens when the North pole of one magnet is brought near the North pole of another magnet?
questions.explanation_correct: Like poles (North-North or South-South) repel each other. When two North poles are brought near each other, they push away from each other. This is a fundamental property of magnets.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Like poles always repel each other. North-North repel, and South-South repel. Only unlike poles (North-South) attract. Two North poles will push each other away.

questions.question_text: What happens when the North pole of one magnet is brought near the South pole of another magnet?
questions.explanation_correct: Unlike poles (North-South) attract each other. When a North pole is brought near a South pole, they pull towards each other. This is a fundamental property of magnets: unlike poles attract.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Unlike poles always attract each other. N-S attract, while N-N or S-S repel. Bringing magnets near each other does not cause them to lose their magnetism.

questions.question_text: Like poles of a magnet ___ each other, while unlike poles ___ each other.
questions.explanation_correct: Like poles (N-N or S-S) repel (push away from) each other. Unlike poles (N-S) attract (pull towards) each other. This is one of the most important properties of magnets.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'repel, attract.' Like poles push away (repel) and unlike poles pull towards (attract) each other.

questions.question_text: Which of the following materials is attracted by a magnet?
questions.explanation_correct: An iron nail is made of iron, which is a magnetic material. Magnets attract materials made of iron, nickel, cobalt, and steel. Plastic, wood, and rubber are non-magnetic materials.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plastic, wood, and rubber are all non-magnetic materials — they are not attracted by magnets. Only iron (and other magnetic materials like nickel, cobalt, steel) are attracted by magnets.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a non-magnetic material?
questions.explanation_correct: Glass is a non-magnetic material — it is not attracted by a magnet. Iron, nickel, and cobalt are all magnetic materials that are attracted by magnets.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Iron, nickel, and cobalt are all magnetic materials. Glass is a non-magnetic material and is not attracted by a magnet.

questions.question_text: A magnet can attract all metals.
questions.explanation_correct: A magnet does NOT attract all metals. It attracts only iron, nickel, cobalt, and steel. Metals like aluminium, copper, gold, and silver are not attracted by magnets. So the statement is false.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is false. Magnets attract only certain metals — iron, nickel, cobalt, and steel. Many metals like copper, aluminium, gold, and silver are not attracted by magnets.

questions.question_text: A freely suspended magnet always points in which direction?
questions.explanation_correct: When a magnet is freely suspended (hung by a thread so it can rotate), it always aligns itself in the north-south direction. The North pole of the magnet points towards the geographic north.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A freely suspended magnet does not point east-west, up-down, or randomly. It always aligns along the north-south direction. This property is used in magnetic compasses.

questions.question_text: A magnetic compass is used to find:
questions.explanation_correct: A magnetic compass contains a small magnetic needle that freely rotates and always points in the north-south direction. By knowing where north is, we can find all other directions. It is used for navigation and finding directions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A compass is not used for temperature, time, or weight. It contains a magnetic needle that points north-south and is used to find directions.

questions.question_text: Which of the following methods can be used to make a magnet?

options.text: Rubbing an iron bar with a magnet in one direction
Dipping an iron bar in water

questions.explanation_correct: An iron bar can be magnetised by rubbing (stroking) it with a magnet repeatedly in the same direction. This is called the stroking method. Heating actually demagnetises a magnet.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Heating destroys magnetism rather than creating it. Dipping in water and painting have no effect on magnetism. Rubbing an iron bar with a magnet in one direction (stroking method) is the correct way to make a magnet.

questions.question_text: Which of the following will cause a magnet to lose its magnetism?

options.text: Keeping it in a dry place
Placing it on a wooden table

questions.explanation_correct: Heating a magnet strongly causes it to lose its magnetism (demagnetisation). Other ways to demagnetise include hammering, dropping repeatedly, and improper storage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Keeping it dry, painting it, or placing it on wood will not affect its magnetism. Strong heating is one of the methods of demagnetisation — the magnet loses its magnetic properties.

questions.question_text: Sunita has two bar magnets. She brings the South pole of the first magnet near the South pole of the second magnet. What will she observe?

options.text: The magnets will attract each other
The magnets will repel each other

questions.explanation_correct: Like poles repel each other. South-South is a like-pole combination, so the magnets will repel (push away from) each other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Like poles (S-S) always repel. They will not attract, and simply bringing two magnets near each other will not demagnetise them.

questions.question_text: If you break a bar magnet into two pieces, what happens?

options.text: One piece will be North and the other South
Both pieces will lose their magnetism
Each piece will have its own North and South pole
The pieces will no longer attract iron

questions.explanation_correct: When a magnet is broken, each piece becomes a complete magnet with its own North and South pole. You cannot isolate a single pole. Even the smallest piece of a magnet will always have both poles.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Breaking a magnet does not create isolated poles or destroy magnetism. Each piece becomes an independent magnet with both a North and a South pole.

questions.question_text: Ravi mixed iron filings with sand. To separate them, he should use:
questions.explanation_correct: Iron filings are magnetic and will be attracted by a magnet. By moving a magnet through the mixture, the iron filings will stick to the magnet and can be separated from the non-magnetic sand.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Water and filter paper are used for other types of separation. A sieve separates by size, which would not work if the iron filings and sand grains are similar in size. A magnet is the best tool because it selectively attracts only the iron filings.

questions.question_text: A magnetic compass needle points towards the north. Which pole of the compass needle is pointing north?
questions.explanation_correct: The North-seeking pole (North pole) of the compass needle points towards the geographic north. This is why it is called the North pole — because it seeks (points towards) the north.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The North pole of the compass needle points towards geographic north. The South pole points towards geographic south. Only one pole points north, and it is the North pole.

questions.question_text: From the following list, identify ALL the magnetic materials: iron, copper, nickel, aluminium, cobalt, gold.
questions.explanation_correct: Iron, nickel, and cobalt are the three main magnetic materials — they are attracted by magnets. Copper, aluminium, and gold are non-magnetic metals and are not attracted by magnets.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Not all metals are magnetic. Copper, aluminium, and gold are not attracted by magnets. Only iron, nickel, and cobalt (and alloys containing them, like steel) are magnetic.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a shape of an artificial magnet?
questions.explanation_correct: Common shapes of artificial magnets include bar (rectangular), horseshoe (U-shaped), cylindrical, and ring magnets. Triangular magnets are not a standard shape of artificial magnets.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bar magnets, horseshoe magnets, and ring magnets are all common artificial magnet shapes. Triangular magnets are not a standard or commonly used shape.

questions.question_text: When making a magnet by the stroking method, why should you always rub in the same direction?

options.text: To align the magnetic domains in one direction, creating a magnet

questions.explanation_correct: Rubbing in the same direction aligns the tiny magnetic regions (domains) inside the iron bar in one direction. When all domains are aligned, the bar becomes a magnet with a definite North and South pole.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The direction matters because consistent stroking in one direction aligns the magnetic domains. Rubbing back and forth would not align them properly. The purpose is not to heat or polish the bar.

questions.question_text: Sailors and travellers used magnetic compasses in ancient times primarily for:
questions.explanation_correct: Magnetic compasses were used by sailors and travellers for navigation — finding directions at sea where there are no landmarks. The compass needle always points north, helping them determine their direction of travel.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Compasses are used for finding directions only. They cannot measure temperature, cook food, or communicate. Navigation was their primary use, especially at sea.

questions.question_text: The magnetic force is strongest at the middle of a bar magnet.
questions.explanation_correct: The magnetic force is strongest at the poles (ends) of a bar magnet, not at the middle. The middle of a magnet has the weakest magnetic force. If you dip a bar magnet into iron filings, you will see more filings clinging to the poles than to the middle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is false. The magnetic strength is maximum at the poles (the two ends) and minimum at the centre of a bar magnet.

questions.question_text: How should bar magnets be stored to prevent them from losing their magnetism?

options.text: Keep pairs of magnets with unlike poles together, separated by wooden or cardboard spacers, with keeper bars across the ends
Drop them from a height regularly

questions.explanation_correct: To preserve magnetism, bar magnets should be stored in pairs with unlike poles facing each other, with a piece of wood between them, and keeper bars (soft iron pieces) placed across their ends. This creates a closed loop for magnetic field lines.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Keeping magnets in water has no benefit. Heating and dropping destroy magnetism. Proper storage with keeper bars and correct pole arrangement preserves magnetic strength.

questions.question_text: A student tested whether a steel key and a brass key are magnetic. She brought a magnet near both. The steel key was attracted but the brass key was not. This shows that:

options.text: Only materials containing iron are magnetic; brass is not magnetic
The brass key was too heavy

questions.explanation_correct: Steel contains iron, which is magnetic, so the steel key is attracted. Brass is an alloy of copper and zinc, neither of which is magnetic, so the brass key is not attracted. This shows that only materials containing magnetic elements (iron, nickel, cobalt) are magnetic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Not all metals are magnetic. The magnet being weak or the brass key being heavy is not the reason. Brass is made of copper and zinc (non-magnetic metals), while steel contains iron (a magnetic metal).

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about natural and artificial magnets is CORRECT?

options.text: Natural magnets are stronger than artificial magnets
Artificial magnets can be made in desired shapes and strengths
Natural magnets come in bar shapes only
Artificial magnets are found in nature

questions.explanation_correct: One major advantage of artificial magnets is that they can be manufactured in any desired shape (bar, horseshoe, ring, cylindrical) and strength. Natural magnets (lodestone) have irregular shapes and are generally weaker than artificial magnets.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Natural magnets are usually weaker than artificial magnets, come in irregular (not bar) shapes, and artificial magnets are made by humans, not found in nature. Artificial magnets can be made in specific shapes and strengths.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: If a bar magnet is broken into two halves, we get one North pole piece and one South pole piece.
Reason: A magnet always has two poles.
Which of the following is correct?

options.text: Both assertion and reason are correct
The assertion is incorrect but the reason is correct
Both assertion and reason are incorrect
The assertion is correct but the reason is incorrect

questions.explanation_correct: The reason is correct — every magnet always has two poles. However, the assertion is incorrect. When you break a magnet, you do NOT get separate North and South pieces. Each piece becomes a complete magnet with its own North and South pole.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reason is true — magnets always have two poles. But the assertion is wrong. Breaking a magnet does not isolate the poles. Each half becomes an independent magnet with both N and S poles.

questions.question_text: Two magnets are placed near each other and they move towards each other. Which poles are facing each other?
questions.explanation_correct: If two magnets move towards each other (attract), unlike poles must be facing each other — North and South. Like poles (N-N or S-S) would repel, pushing the magnets apart.
questions.explanation_incorrect: N-N or S-S would cause repulsion (magnets moving apart). Since the magnets are moving towards each other (attraction), the facing poles must be unlike — North and South.

questions.question_text: A magnet is placed inside a cardboard box. Iron filings are scattered on top of the box. What will happen to the iron filings?

options.text: Nothing — the cardboard blocks the magnetic effect
The iron filings will be attracted and arrange themselves in a pattern above the magnet
The iron filings will fly away
The cardboard will become a magnet

questions.explanation_correct: Magnetic force can pass through non-magnetic materials like cardboard, paper, and plastic. The iron filings on top of the box will be attracted by the magnet below and will arrange themselves in a pattern showing the magnetic effect.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cardboard is non-magnetic and does not block magnetic force. The magnet's attraction passes through the cardboard and attracts the iron filings. Cardboard does not become a magnet, and the filings will not fly away.

questions.question_text: If the North pole of a compass needle points towards a particular end of a bar magnet, that end of the bar magnet is the:
questions.explanation_correct: The North pole of the compass is attracted towards the South pole of the bar magnet (unlike poles attract). If the compass North points towards a bar magnet end, that end must be the South pole.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Unlike poles attract. If the North pole of the compass points towards a particular end of the bar magnet, that end must be the opposite pole — the South pole. Like poles would repel.

questions.question_text: Which of the following will NOT demagnetise a magnet?

options.text: Keeping the magnet in a dry, cool place with keeper bars
Dropping the magnet from a great height

questions.explanation_correct: Keeping a magnet in a cool, dry place with keeper bars is actually the proper way to store magnets and preserve their magnetism. Heating, hammering, and dropping all cause demagnetisation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Heating, hammering, and dropping all cause magnets to lose their magnetism. Proper storage in a cool, dry place with keeper bars helps preserve magnetism, not destroy it.

questions.question_text: Where on a bar magnet is the power of attraction the greatest?
questions.explanation_correct: The magnetic force is strongest at the poles of a bar magnet. If you dip a bar magnet in iron filings, you will see that most filings cling to the two ends (poles) and very few stick to the middle.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The magnetic force is NOT the same everywhere on a magnet. It is strongest at the poles (ends) and weakest at the centre. This can be demonstrated with the iron filings experiment.

questions.question_text: A student brings a magnet near the following objects one by one: paper clip, glass marble, iron screw, aluminium can, steel safety pin. Which objects will be attracted?

options.text: Paper clip, glass marble, aluminium can
Paper clip, iron screw, steel safety pin
Glass marble, aluminium can, steel safety pin

questions.explanation_correct: Paper clips are usually made of steel (contains iron), iron screws are made of iron, and steel safety pins contain iron — all are magnetic. Glass marbles and aluminium cans are non-magnetic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Glass and aluminium are non-magnetic materials. Only objects made of iron, nickel, cobalt, or their alloys (like steel) are attracted by magnets. Paper clips (steel), iron screws, and steel safety pins are all magnetic.

questions.question_text: A magnet is suspended freely by a thread. After it stops swinging, you rotate it away from its resting position and release it. What will happen?

options.text: It will stay in the new position
It will return to point in the north-south direction again

questions.explanation_correct: A freely suspended magnet always aligns itself in the north-south direction. If you rotate it and release it, it will swing back and eventually settle in the north-south direction again.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The magnet will not stay in a random position, spin forever, or lose magnetism. It will always return to its preferred north-south alignment because of the Earth's magnetic field.

questions.question_text: Two bar magnets are placed end to end and they stick together. The poles in contact must be:

options.text: One North and one South pole

questions.explanation_correct: If two magnets stick together, they are attracting each other. Attraction occurs only between unlike poles. So the poles in contact must be one North pole and one South pole.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Same poles (N-N or S-S) repel each other and would push apart. Only unlike poles (N and S) attract, causing the magnets to stick together.

questions.question_text: Copper is a magnetic material because it is a metal.
questions.explanation_correct: Being a metal does not automatically make a material magnetic. Copper is a metal but it is NOT magnetic — it is not attracted by magnets. Only iron, nickel, cobalt, and their alloys (like steel) are magnetic.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This statement is false. Not all metals are magnetic. Copper, aluminium, gold, and silver are metals that are not attracted by magnets. Only specific metals (iron, nickel, cobalt) are magnetic.

questions.question_text: Renu wraps an insulated wire around an iron nail and connects the wire to a battery. The iron nail starts attracting paper clips. What has the iron nail become?
questions.explanation_correct: When wire carrying electric current is wrapped around an iron nail, it creates a temporary magnet called an electromagnet. The iron nail becomes magnetic only when current flows through the wire and loses magnetism when the current is switched off.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is not a permanent magnet because the magnetism disappears when the current stops. It is not a natural magnet because it was made using electricity. It is an electromagnet — a temporary magnet created by electric current.

questions.question_text: Which of the following lists contains ONLY shapes of artificial magnets?
questions.explanation_correct: Bar, horseshoe, cylindrical, and ring are all shapes of artificial magnets made by humans. Lodestone and magnetite are natural magnets with irregular shapes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Lodestone and magnetite are natural magnets, not artificial. Only bar, horseshoe, cylindrical, and ring are shapes of artificial magnets.

questions.question_text: Two freely suspended magnets are placed near each other. The North pole of magnet A is near the South pole of magnet B. What will happen?

options.text: They will attract each other and come closer

questions.explanation_correct: Unlike poles attract each other. The North pole of magnet A and the South pole of magnet B are unlike poles, so they will attract and move towards each other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Unlike poles (N of A and S of B) always attract. They will not repel, ignore each other, or both point east. The attraction will pull them closer together.

questions.question_text: Which of the following statements about demagnetisation is INCORRECT?

options.text: Heating a magnet can demagnetise it
Hammering a magnet can demagnetise it
Rubbing a magnet with another magnet in one direction demagnetises it
Dropping a magnet repeatedly can demagnetise it

questions.explanation_correct: Rubbing an iron piece with a magnet in one direction does NOT demagnetise — it actually magnetises the iron piece (stroking method). Heating, hammering, and dropping are all methods of demagnetisation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Heating (A), hammering (B), and dropping (D) all cause demagnetisation. But rubbing with a magnet in one direction (C) is a method of making a magnet, not destroying magnetism.

questions.question_text: A magnet can attract iron objects through a thin barrier of paper or cardboard. This is because:

options.text: Magnetic force can pass through non-magnetic materials
The paper becomes transparent to light

questions.explanation_correct: Magnetic force can act through non-magnetic materials like paper, cardboard, glass, and plastic. These materials do not block or absorb magnetic force, allowing the magnet to attract iron objects through them.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Paper and cardboard are not magnetic. Iron objects do not become lighter. Light transparency is unrelated. The correct reason is that magnetic force can penetrate non-magnetic materials.

questions.question_text: The maximum attraction of a bar magnet is at its ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The poles (ends) of a bar magnet have the maximum magnetic strength. The iron filings experiment clearly shows that more filings cling to the poles than to any other part of the magnet.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct answer is 'poles.' The magnetic strength is greatest at the two poles (ends) of a bar magnet and weakest at the centre.

questions.question_text: If you have a bar magnet whose poles are not marked, how can you identify its North pole?

options.text: By suspending it freely and seeing which end points towards geographic north

questions.explanation_correct: Suspend the bar magnet freely using a thread. After it stops swinging, it will align in the north-south direction. The end pointing towards geographic north is the North pole of the magnet.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Colour, weight, and water do not help identify poles. The correct method is to suspend the magnet freely — the end pointing towards geographic north is the North pole.

questions.question_text: A horseshoe magnet is shaped like the letter:
questions.explanation_correct: A horseshoe magnet is shaped like the letter 'U' (or like a horseshoe used on horse hooves). Both poles are close together at the open end, giving it a strong magnetic force at that end.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A horseshoe magnet is U-shaped, not I-shaped (that would be a bar), O-shaped (that would be a ring), or L-shaped.

questions.question_text:
Match the following:
(i) Iron nail – P. Non-magnetic
(ii) Glass bead – Q. Magnetic
(iii) Steel pin – R. Non-magnetic
(iv) Wooden block – S. Magnetic
The correct match is:
questions.explanation_correct: Iron nail is magnetic (Q). Glass bead is non-magnetic (P). Steel pin is magnetic (S — steel contains iron). Wooden block is non-magnetic (R).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Iron and steel are magnetic materials. Glass and wood are non-magnetic. The correct matching is (i)-Q, (ii)-P, (iii)-S, (iv)-R.

questions.question_text: Which of the following experiments can demonstrate that like poles repel?

options.text: Bring the North pole of a magnet near an iron nail
Suspend a bar magnet and bring the North pole of another magnet near its North pole
Place a magnet in iron filings
Place a magnet near a wooden block

questions.explanation_correct: By suspending one magnet and bringing the same pole (North) of another magnet near the suspended magnet's North pole, you will see the suspended magnet swing away (repel). This directly demonstrates that like poles repel.
questions.explanation_incorrect: An iron nail is attracted to any pole (not repulsion). Iron filings show the magnetic field pattern. A wooden block is non-magnetic. Only bringing same poles near each other (N near N) demonstrates repulsion.

questions.question_text: An electromagnet is different from a permanent magnet because an electromagnet:

options.text: Can be switched on and off by controlling the electric current

questions.explanation_correct: The key difference is that an electromagnet works only when electric current flows through the coil. It can be turned on (magnetised) and off (demagnetised) by controlling the current. A permanent magnet cannot be switched on or off.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Electromagnets are not always stronger than permanent magnets. They have two poles just like any magnet. They can attract iron when turned on. The unique feature is that they can be controlled by switching current on and off.

questions.question_text: A compass needle always shows the same direction no matter where you stand in a room. This property is used to:

options.text: Measure the area of the room
Find which direction is north and navigate accordingly
Measure the temperature of the room

questions.explanation_correct: The compass needle always points in the north-south direction because of the Earth's magnetism. This consistent directional property makes it useful for navigation — finding north and determining all other directions from it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A compass cannot measure area, temperature, or weight. Its sole use is to indicate direction by consistently pointing towards magnetic north.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following statements:
(i) Natural magnets are found in nature as rocks.
(ii) Artificial magnets can only be made in the bar shape.
(iii) Magnetite is another name for lodestone.
Which of the above statements is/are correct?
questions.explanation_correct: Statement (i) is correct — natural magnets (lodestone/magnetite) are found as rocks in nature. Statement (iii) is correct — magnetite and lodestone are the same thing. Statement (ii) is incorrect — artificial magnets can be made in many shapes (bar, horseshoe, ring, cylindrical).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Statement (ii) is wrong because artificial magnets come in many shapes, not just bar. Statements (i) and (iii) are both correct — lodestone and magnetite are the same natural magnetic rock.

questions.question_text: You have two identical-looking iron bars. One is a magnet and the other is not. Without using any other magnet or compass, how can you identify which one is the magnet?

options.text: Weigh both bars — the magnet will be heavier
Touch the middle of one bar to the end of the other; if it attracts, the bar being touched at its end is the magnet
Place both bars in water and see which one floats

Touch the end of one bar to the middle of the other; if there is attraction, the bar whose middle is being touched is the magnet, since a magnet's centre has weak attraction but an iron bar is attracted uniformly

questions.explanation_correct: A magnet has maximum attraction at its poles and almost no attraction at its centre. If you touch the end of bar A to the middle of bar B and there is strong attraction, bar B must be the ordinary iron bar (attracted uniformly). If there is weak or no attraction, bar B is the magnet (weak at centre). This difference helps identify which is the magnet.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Weight and floating do not help — both bars are identical iron. The key insight is that a magnet's centre is its weakest point. By testing attraction at the middle versus the ends, you can identify which bar is magnetised.
